subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. This species resembles
A. parvula Thorell, 1877
( Figs 9â€“10 ), but can be distinguished from the latter by the distal end of median apophysis somewhat like the head of a cobra snake, with bent tip ( Figs 7Aâ€“B , 8Dâ€“E ), whereas distal end curved triangular with ventrally bent tip in
A. parvula
( Figs 9Aâ€“B , 10Dâ€“E ), basoembolic apophysis longer than wide, highly sclerotized ( Figs 7A, C , 8D, F ), whereas almost round and not sclerotized in
A. parvula
( Figs 9A, C , 10Dâ€“F ). Posterior margin of epigyne straight ( Figs 7Dâ€“E , 8Gâ€“H ), whereas posterior margin with a depression in
A. parvula
( Figs 9Dâ€“E , 10Gâ€“H ). Spermathecal head not furcated ( Figs 7E , 8H ), whereas furcated into two branches in
A. parvula
( Figs 9E , 10H ).

Description. See
Li et al. (2012)
for both sexes. Habitus, male pedipalp, and epigyne as in Figs 7â€“8 .

Distribution. Previously known from Yunnan Province of China only, but here reported from further east and north, to the Guizhou and Sichuan Provinces of China ( Fig. 11 ).
